description.text: This is a replacement for the thread spool holder on an IKEA sewing machine. It is for the external spool, not the one underneath. It snaps in where the original goes, but it is a little tight. You could try shrinking it by a few percent as well.

comments.text:
Thank you so much for this, my machine was useless without it. Printed it and it fit after some tweaking.
Machine - Creality CR-10s
Print material - PLA
Print temrerature - 110C
Print speed - 50mm/s
Retraction - 5mm @ 40mm/s
Print resolution (cura) 'fine' 0.1mm
Print time - 48 mins
Printed horizontally with an 8mm brim, no supports.
100% infill
Some manual finishing required to remove brim after printing.
Sanded thickness down on hinge end and increased taper.
Cut a slot down the center of hinge end with a junior hack saw to allow compression for fitting.
All these modifications could easily be done prior to printing, unfortunately I am a total noob on blender and do not have the skills yet.

description.text:
I have taken the dimensions from several different arcaswiss rail copies and modified them to work well as 3d printed parts. All of the corners contain a fillet which prevents part delamination often seen in 3d parts where sharp angles terminate when they are put under load. The two slots in this rail can contain a 1/4-20 quick release bolt with a 12mm diameter or smaller head which should be no more than 5mm thick.

I am using 3D XTech Carbon Fiber PETG and it works beautifully for functioning parts, this adapter easily holds a 200mm F3.5 lens and dslr without the slightest sign of flexure. I recommend petg over PLA or ABS because it does not absorb moisture, the oil in your hands will not compromise the structural properties of petg, a hot car is not going to have any negative effect on the petg, also I have tested my parts down to 17f and they did not become brittle. So its a nice plastic to use, especially when you go the carbon fiber route which is extremely rigid. The carbon does need to be hit with an 800 grit sanding sponge as it will develop some rough surface fibers, it takes about 5 minutes to clean up.

author: kttrend

description.text:
This is actually a modified version of https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2637702, but instead of subtracting the bumps from the basic vase shape, I added them. I originally started out with hexagonal bumps, but these these just didn't look right, so I switched to circles. (Actually the bumps are modified hemispheres.) The basic shape of this vase is based on similarly shaped early Native American pottery. Those had no bumps of course, but were usually painted with fancy designs.
To save time you might like to know the bumps are arranged in 27 columns of 33 bumps each, for a total of 891 bumps. This part printed in just under 15 hours at a print speed of 80 mm/sec and a layer height of 0.200 mm.

Altered the body and head so that the head sits on top of the body instead of the other way around. I was trying to use this as a decoration and the head kept falling down.

Great original model by the way!

title: Mini Mill Z axis CNC conversion

description.text:
Two options to convert your mini mill's Z axis to CNC.

"Z final" is an adapter which allows you to direct drive the rack and pinion. There is not a lot of mechanical advantage here, and there is also quite a bit of backlash. But it is the quickest and easiest.

The other two prints combine to use a leadscrew drive which provides a fair bit of mechanical advantage over the rack and pinion (4:1 if you use an 8mm leadscrew). The top print centers the motor, the bottom print fits over the mill and holds the leadscrew nut. In addition you need a leadscrew, leadscrew nut, NEMA stepper and a coupler between the motor and the leadscrew (I turned this on a lathe). I also use a thrust bearing on the bottom to carry most of the load from the leadscrew as opposed to hanging from the stepper motor.

Blog post: http://harborfreightcnc.blogspot.com/2017/11/z-axis.html
X axis: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2586512
Y axis: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2591938

I know this entry is brief; if people are interested in replicating I'm happy to flesh out in greater detail. My X and Y axis conversion have gotten some likes/collections but no makes that I am aware of. If people decide to start making I'm happy to flesh out in further detail.

This is our remix of the awesome Hulk Ragnarok model by Masterclip, the model was completely remeshed and smooth sculpted and has a flat base.

One of the pictures above is of a 3D print made on our FlashForge Finder, awesome printer with software that can also generate organic support beams. (Affiliate link: https://www.gearbest.com/3d-printers-3d-printer-kits/pp_693032.html?lkid=11324000) The print was painted dark copper afterwards, the support material came off very easy.

I added a version holding the hammer too, the hammer was made by Killonious.

And I added the first model with support beams, it was generated with FlashPrint. This way you can slice with support off and remove the pillars easily after printing.

author: kttrend

description.text:
This is a spool holder for Mendel Max 2. A nice feature is that the holder itself just hangs securely on the frame without needing to be permanently attached. To complete the holder, a 12mm tube/dowel needs to be inserted. Make it long enough that the spool will be out of the way of the Z-axis of the MM2. For this, you will need a little spacer or something to keep the spool from sliding down the tube/dowel. The axis that the spool rotates on has a slight angle that keeps the spool from coming off the end.
This thing is quite strong by design, and can easily hold 2 spools with a good print. One of my first FDM designs :) I will upload photos eventually. Edit: Forgot to mention, you need to put at least 1 bolt+T-Nut on the top part where the bolt holes are. The T-Nut goes on the side where the protrusion that holds the spool axis is.

author: September23

description.text: I needed a key housing for my 2005 Honda Pilot - 3 button remote. Thanks to Cleven for the original design. It eliminated a lot of extra work. I really didn't need a hole for the key ring. I had difficulty with the snap clasp. And, I managed to break the cover on my maiden voyage to the grocery store. So, I figured I'd make the closure more rigid by using an M3 hex bolt instead of a plastic snap. I thickened the cover. I figure that most people building anything from this site probably have a bunch of M3's lying around. I added posts to two overhangs on the back cover. So, no support material is needed. Just clip them away after printing. I increased the size of the interior cavity to fit my remote circuit and the sensor chip. (If you haven't done this before, Honda sticks a theft prevention sensor chip inside their keys. If you have a busted case, and you didn't pull out the sensor chip when extracting the remote circuitry, then fish the case out of the garbage. You'll need it. The engine will turn over, but the car won't start without the sensor chip in close proximity to the ignition switch. The sensor chip just goes in the key case next to the remote circuit. Picture is pre-finished. After 2 days of driving around under duress with kids in the back seat, no cracking or breaks (me or the key.) If it breaks after a while, I might add an interior pocket for the sensor chip to keep it from rattling.

description.text:
This is a replacement pin for a Lascal Buggy Board (the pin connects the buggy board to the strap that attaches to the buggy)

My wife lost one of the pins and a replacement set of pins would have cost £25, which considering the buggy board cost £6 on ebay seemed like a bit much.

So I designed this replacement, it is basically exactly the same as the original, and fits perfectly, (see pictures- the red one is the original, and the black one is the copy)

Printer:

Malyan M150

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

100%

Notes:

Printed in PLA at 100% infill with no supports, on my M150 this came out really well, I was surprised that it did to be honest as the pin is quite small, I printed one at a time, but if you have problems, try printing more than one so the nozzle isn't over one small area all the time.

I was also surprised that the pin is strong enough, being printed in PLA, but PLA is acutally more rigid than ABS so maybe that helps in this instance. Certainly it is holding up well on our buggy board.
Designed in Autodesk Inventor, I drew a half side profile without the thread, and used revolve. Then added the thread by drawing a small rectangle and then using coil around the pin.

title: X Axis Motor Mount and Idler - Angular Style

description.text:
Key facts - Distance between center for x smooth rod and x leadscrew - 22mm

Updates - 12/11/2017

Added version with 44mm distance between x smooth rod centers.
Fractional change to dimensions of tension part for improved fit.
Added variant of 44mm distance version for users who tension on the carriage rather than via the idler.

The sets:

46mm distance between x smooth rods set:
1x x_motor_Angular.stl
1x x_idler_Angular.stl
1x x_tension_Angular.stl

44mm distance between x smooth rods set:
1x x_motor_Angular_44mm.stl
1x x_idler_Angular_44mm.stl
1x x_tension_Angular_44mm.stl

44mm distance between x smooth rods without x tension:
1x x_motor_Angular_44mm.stl
1x x_idler_Angular_44mm_no_tension.stl

This is my second version of the x axis parts - motor, idler and external tension part.

I created this version because my previous design obstructs access to the x motor pulley grub screws which makes adjustment more awkward than necessary.

It retains the interior angles to aid in printing without supports wherever possible. The only part that should require supports is the tensioning part. Supports should be placed under the screw hole at the bottom of the model, in the middle where the x idler pulley is mounted and under the two parts that enter the side of the x idler part.

Each model is designed to be printed in the orientation presented in the files.

As usual I would consider making variations on the design if someone particularly wants an internal x idler (for example).

title: U Clip For Greenhouses
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: Parametric U shaped clip for clipping sheeting to PVC piping for building custom cold frames and greenhouses. Using Schedule 40 White PVC pipe is a common way to build your own designs for green houses, cold frames etc. For example: http://doorgarden.com/10/50-dollar-hoop-house-green-house This U Clip is used to attach clear sheeting or netting to the frame. The stl's are for 3/4 inch PVC (approx 1 inch outside diameter), but the design is parametric, so you can change it for any diameter of piping. Printed at 100%, the result is strong. I've put it through 60 clip/unclip cycles over single and double sheeting, and had no breakage or looseness.
Print at 100% and 1 shell.  Sand any sharp edges and push to clip on.

Yes.
The photo shows the holder with a 1kg PET filament spool.

title: QR Code Dog Tag
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is simple dog tag with a QR Code, where you can encode URL or other contact information. The model is parametric and its size adapts to amount of data encoded in the QR code.

To generate the qr_data variable holding the QR Code data, use my OpenSCAD QR Code Generator.

The SCAD file generates two objects, you are supposed to glue them back to back with superglue and form a single badge. The model requires Prusa ColorPrint or other similar software, which allows you to modify G-Code to change filament during print. It does not require dual extrusion etc.

This is my first project : my take on the Mario's Star Coin. It was a pain designing the star itself, but I can't be more satisfied with the results!

I've designed it at first for making tokens for the Monopoly's Gamer's Edition currency, but it does make a great collectible item for a Nintendo fan.

It prints best vertically with only touching buildplate support, since the star prints perfectly without. I've tried it at 1/3 scaling and it prints okay for the tokens, but not perfect detail-wise.
I've only tried PLA at 20% Infill yet though.

Suggestions are welcome !

description.text:
This is a two channel (I,Q) magnetic tach for the popular 755 and 775 dc brushed motors. It is very low cost (less than $1), will operate at very high RPM, and provides accurately phased, glitchless I and Q outputs. 11/18/2017 Replaced the Solidworks file with a revision which greattly improves parametric range. Magnet circle diameter can range from 24mm to over 50mm with proper result, and magnet generation is fixed.

title: Anycubic Kossel Linear Plus E3D V6 Effector

description.text:
I made the connecting rod mounting points longer so I don't have to use the copper spacers anymore.
They are 52mm wide without spacers.
I added a small round brim under each mounting point to help minimize warping. Trim away post print.
I added a nut pocket so I can use a 3mm X 20mm bolt with a nut and with the rod end installed, the bolt will just reach the nut.

I have noticed with repeated assembly and disassembly that the mounting hole for the E3D will start to get a little loose, so I added 3 screw holes pointing in towards the center, to help lock down the E3D.
The top collar does a pretty good job of holding it secure, but it is better with the 3 screws. Just don't over tighten them, snug is enough.

The top collar - will take (2) 3mm x 15-20mm screws and nuts. 20's will work but 15's look a little better.

I have 2 square holes on each side. You can either pass wires through the holes, or use the holes as anchor points for wire ties, or use my little wire clips.

I made a holder for my bore scope, a tiny camera inside a 10mm diameter housing.

I made a stand for my effector with the extended rod bearing anchor points. Makes it a little easier to work on. Also doubles as a display stand for your spares.

I am still working on the carriages. I have them printed but not installed yet. Same thing, no copper spacers. The rod end mounting points are 52mm wide. These were just a very minor remix. I placed the nut pockets on top because, well, gravity sucks. I added a tiny brim and support for accuracy and non warping. Trim away post print.

I re-mixed (again) some carriages that really are belt tensioners too.
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2653647

I printed these in ABS with 50% infill.

print_settings.Notes:: reduce jitter and speed

title: Dungeons and Dragons D&D; Battle Tokens
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
An (incomplete) set of battle tokens for Dungeons and Dragons. Each token is inscribed in a circle of 15mm radius. Designed in Rhino.

Note: if you use a standard grid size you need to scale these down to 50%.

The set includes:

  • ten numbered tokens from 0 to 9
  • one token with the symbol of Pelor
  • one token with the symbol of Fharlanghn
  • one token with a two edged axe
  • one token with a (spell) book
  • one token with a lute

Provided STL:

  • TokenXXX.stl individual token
  • TokensAll.stl all the tokens
  • TokenEmpty.stl the empty octagonal base
  • SymbolYYY.stl the symbol for the non-numeric tokens

Printer:

CR-10

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.06

Infill:

100%

Notes:

I printed these at 50% size (i.e. standard grid size, 15mm). The small features seem to be hard for my printer to realise.

I suggest to

  • reduce jitter and speed
  • use the best quality settings available
  • add supports, at least for the non-numeric tokens
  • reduce line width as much as possible

I designed everything in Rhino. The font used for the numeric tokens is Farisi.

The remaining tokens were drawn with not that much accuracy (except for Pelor's symbol which is geometrically interesting and easy enough to assemble) given that these fit in a 3x3cm square.

Designing the lute
The lute is a sphere that I deformed using the cage (Points on). I sliced it in a half using a plane and and the Trim command. I repeated the process for a sphere that I added as the sound hole. The rest of the body are just boxes. I used Planar surface and Boolean union for the rest.

Designing the book
I first draw a curved line as the page profile, and added a slope. I used Mirror on a x- and y-axis, and deformed the curves to give more variety. I added cross section lines at the ends of the profile curves and used Sweep2 for generating the page block. I then used Planar surf and a box, together with Boolean union.

Designing the axe
I drew the edge profile of one blade, then I drew the profile height at the blade-handle joint. I added a curve between the middle of the blade-handle joint to the edge to show how the object shrinks towards the edge. I copied the curve and moved the interpolation points along the edge to create some more intermediate variation, and used Sweep2 for creating the blade profile (the two rails are the edge and the blade-edge profile, the other curves the cross sections). The rest is just cylinders and cones.

Designing Fharlanghn's symbol
I started drawing two arcs. I then used Arc: start, end, radius using the previous arc's start and end, but a different radius, to add some thickness to the holes. I used Tween curve to get an intermediate curve between the two radii. Using Points on, I moved the intermediate points of the tweened curve a few millimiters down. I created the two walls of each of the two arcs's cut using a Loft command (two curves and a loft with Simple loft works perfectly). I added the profile of the edge as a curve, revolved it and used Planar surface to get the remaining pieces.

Designing Pelor's symbol
I started from the pointy spikes. I drew a curve for the spike joint's profile, and made a 90deg-rotated copy (along the blade axis). I added two straight lines and used Sweep2 to get one of the four walls that make up the spike joint. I used Extrude to point to make the spike's blade, taking as curve one of the two edges. Using Mirror twice, along the x- and z-axis, yields a full spike. I made 12 copied of that. Then I added a Star using the polygon tool, scaled it down and moved it along z. I added some cross section curves between two vertices and used Sweep2 (closed sweep) to get the star's sloped section. I added cylinders where needed and Trimmed off the excesses. Planar surf completed the shape.

Designing the numerical tokens
I created the text as a 3D solid and used the Boolean union tool. This is by far the fastest method, although some care must be taken: for the token no. 4, for example, the resulting surface was not correct. I had to get the text as curves, Explode them, Rebuild them, Join them back and Extrude (Crv) them into the number 4's profile. Apparently something was wrong with those curves. Also pay attention because sometimes there are very short curves that make up the tighter corners of the font's glyphs.

title: LED Persistence of Vision Display for Teal Sport Drone

description.text:
Persistence of Vision LED Strip Display Mounts + Parametric and Printable Drone Case + LED Control Circuit for the Teal Sport Drone

  • I'm publishing this thing before I've finalized several details, because a couple of the files I've made might be a nice starting point for someone else to make a top case mod, and there's enough time left that they might get to make use of them. :)

You know what'd go great with a crazy fast drone? Adding a high-speed LED Persistence-of-Vision display! Turn it into a ballistic neon skywriter.

With the right speed combinations, you could flash pictures of your team logo, your sponsors, or, uh, a picture of your cat?

Since it's a drop in stock-like cover for the Teal Sport, you could swap in the POV LED mount for exhibitions, warmup runs, or whatever else you do with an absurdly fast flying machine. Rep your team. Or your cat.

Or just set it to a random color pattern and watch it go.

For a drone this small and carefully tuned, there will be a performance hit, but center of mass should be preserved, and the extra parts are pretty thin and light.

This was designed with help from Makersaurus Rex. Here's a video of the helpers testing a print with an LED strip: https://youtu.be/fjHQqzrXjrc . You can read the story of how dinosaurs got a printer here.

Changes for this project are tracked at Github.

Note: video and pictures were taken using a NeoPixel strip, which have a slower PWM and won't be as good for persistence of vision display as the DotStars, explained below. But they're what I already had and get the eye-searing point across. Seriously, these things are blinding and I'm considering printing a diffuser out of clear filament. The LED holder strip is sized by default to hold a DotStar strip with the weather stripping still attached, but will adjust to fit different LED strip sizes by changing the relevant parameters.

Current Progress:

  • It's pretty much done! There's a library of OpenSCAD shapes anyone can use (why does everyone just post .stl's and not indlude their design files?) and a version with a mix of procedurally generated and hand-tuned supports that should make the final product very printable.

Reviews:

"That is going to be an AMAZING future-tron-air-manta-ray thing."

  • Totally unbiased volunteer design review committee member.

"This looks very cool. How are your job applications coming along?"

  • My Mom.

This project has a few purposes:

  1. Present 3d models and circuit designs to add Persistence-of-Vision LED displays to a Teal port Drone.
  2. Be a drop-in replacement for the top plate with stock-like mounts for the FPV hardware, so your FPV setup will be about the same with and without the LED displays attached.
  3. Be reasonable to print.
    • The plain top cover and a lot of the remixes look great, but they're extremely difficult to print using FDM printers because they're mostly overhang. That has to be addressed to make this into a reasonable project.
    • This design shouldn't be a concept piece; it's ready to print.
    • I don't see a way around the fundamental problem that we're printing the inside of a squashed egg shape, but I've included manually generated supports where I was able, because (unless you're dual-extruding a soluble filament), slicers aren't so great at smart support generation, still.
  4. Create a library of shapes for Teal Drone case mods that is broadly parametric to support changing out similar parts with different dimensions.
    • Pre-baked STL models are great, but if you need to move part of the model exactly 3.1mm to make it fit, or make other precision changes, then life is way easier if the model builder provides source code where dimensions can be changed.
    • This is especially useful for overcoming artifacts from printing or materials, like hole diameters, thermal shrinkage, and overhang artifacts.

The base of this top cover should match the Teal Drone exactly, and that shape was taken from the sample model. The rest of this case is designed from scratch in OpenSCAD to be close to the original shape. (Using approximate geometries.) With everything in parameters, you can make important adjustments for printing, like tweaking the inner diameter of the mounting holes, selectively scaling parts of the overall shape to compensate for filament shrinkage, or defining an internal volume so you can change the thickness or create manual print supports.

Obviously, anyone that wants a more hacker-friendly model as a starting point for this contest is very welcome to use this code! I think these shapes might be an easier starting point for OpenSCAD-centric work.

This project built a couple intermediate stages on the way to the LED holder case design, with the goal of creating a library of shapes that could be used to build many different Teal Sport case mods. All of the component shapes have several parameters collected together in the parameter files for each shape.

The first step was to re-create a shape extremely similar to the plain case.

The next step was to look up the RunCam Swift 2 camera dimensions for an FPV mount. (I couldn't find a dimensional drawing of the Rotor Riot edition, but that's why everything is parameterized; it's easy to fix if wrong.) A SMA jack port and air vent cowlings created a drone case mode that's functionally similar to the stock Teal Sport case.

Once that was completed, adding a bracket mount and screw hole to the side of the case for the LED strip mount was a pretty small task.

Project File Guide:

There's quite a few files in this project.

Most files have an associated file that collects all the parameters that lead to generation of the shapes. There's quite a bit of freedom to move things around by just changing those numbers!

Plain and Stock-Like Part Files: A Case Mod Toolbox
  • teal_top_cover_outline.dxf

This vector file is a vertial projection of the plain case provided by Teal. This shape is used throughout the project to ensure an exact fit.

  • teal_drone_top_cover_plain.scad
    teal_drone_top_cover_plain_parameters.scad
    teal_drone_top_cover_plain.stl

These define the outer and inner volumes of a plain case like the one Teal provided, along with brackets for mounting on the drone body. These form the basis for the rest of the project. I made some effort to reduce interior overhangs below a height parameter, but with this case shape, overhangs are unavoidable.

  • teal_drone_top_cover_stocklike.scad
    teal_drone_top_cover_stocklike_parameters.scad
    teal_drone_top_cover_stocklike.stl

These add an FPV camera mount with tilt adjustment bracket, SMA jack port, and air vents. Each addition is typically an outer volume and interior cutout, permitting changes to be mixed and matched at various positions and angles.

LED Persistence of Vision Display Case Mod Files

Once I was done reinventing the wheel with the above files, I had made a library of shapes and volumes that let you quickly add, remove, or redefine parts for a Teal Sport drone cover.

  • curvy_led_strip_holder.scad
    curvy_led_strip_holder_parameters.scad
    curvy_led_strip_holder.sql

These create a curved strip to hold an LED strip for the persistence-of-vision display. The length and amount of curve are adjustable to stay closer to the rotor body, avoid rotors, or as aesthetic choices. The holder includes a mounting post and tilt adjustment arm, so the LED strip can be oriented at the same angle as the FPV camera. A similar range of angles is possible for both.

  • led_strip_holder_bracket.scad
    led_strip_holder_bracket_parameters.scad
    led_strip_holder_bracket.stl

This is a small bracket with a tilt mount for the LED strip holder. The interior post of the bracket attaches to the top case with an M3 screw, and has a lip that will conform to the shape of the side of the drone for an exact fit to help keep it from wobbling.

  • teal_drone_top_cover_with_side_bracket.scad
    teal_drone_top_cover_with_side_bracket_parameters.scad
    teal_drone_top_cover_with_side_bracket.stl

This is the top cover (without supports) that adds a the attachment for the side bracket and a port for wires. Use this shape the persistence-of-vision print.

  • teal_drone_plus_led_strips_assembled_preview.scad

This file renders all the parts as they should be assembled, along with the rotor collision area specified by Teal, and a very rough rendering of the drone chassis, based on best-guess estimations from looking at pictures.

Custom Procedurally Generated Supports

Drone covers are an extremely difficult shape to print! They're essentially half of a squashed, really bumpy egg, almost entirely steep overhangs, and the overhangs aren't even fully horizontal, so the slicer won't be able to figure out good bridge directions.

Supports for the LED strip holder were pretty easy to generate, though I might go back and make them into full boxes enclosing the overhang area so there's less retractions. There are strip supports for the post and tilt arm, and for the open front bracket. The STL is:

  • curvy_led_strip_holder_supports.stl

I don't think many of the contest entries have put a lot of thought or effort into printability, but this difficult shape really does demand some work there.

Printing the main case will be much more involved. I thought about splitting it in half lengthwise to make two sides so you could print it with the middle of the case, or slicing off the bottom 5-6mm to make an easily printed base section and reduce the height of bridging the rest of it. But both would force you to glue parts together and me to add alignment pins.

Some of the best results I've had downloading and printing things from Thingiverse were when the creators put thin strip supports for key overhands. All these drone cases consist entirely of overhangs, but since I'm generating this one programatically, I can tell it to make supports that match the contours of the different sub-shapes, and then draw support lines perpendicular to the overhangs so that the slicer will tend to put bridges in ways that will succeed. The major downside is you have to break all these supports off, but they'll be on the inside of the drone where the cosmetic bits of leftover support will be less annoying.

The files for the final, very printable version of the case are:

  • teal_drone_top_cover_with_side_bracket_supports.scad
    teal_drone_top_cover_with_side_bracket_supports.stl

Persistence of Vision Display Circuit

One key component of a really fast LED POV display is an LED controller with a fast enough PWM rate to keep up with the rate of motion. That's the APA102 LED, which has a 20KHz PWM rate and is sold in strips as Adafruit's DotStar product.

Luckily for us, this project has pretty much been completely designed and implemented by the awesome Erin St Blaine and other folks over at Adafruit. We'll be starting with her LED POV-spinning Supernova Poi project and with a few small modifications to put it on a drone instead.

(The Genesis Poi: DotStar LED Persistence-of-Vision is similar and looks great, also using the DotStar LED strips, but I have more of the parts for the other version already lying around.)

For convenience, this project adds a microSD card holder so you can have it read images to display from the SD card instead of programming them into the microcontroller in advance.

There's a couple important considerations:

  • Isolate the LED circuit completely from the drone electronics to protect the drone. That's accomplished with a tiny-but-beefy 5V regulator from Pololu.
  • The Supernova Poi project chooses to drive the LED control lines at 3.3V, but most sources say to use 5V, so I included a level shifter for those two lines.
  • The power usage will depend on how many LEDs are used and how brightly they are driven. These are bright LEDs, with peak power for full white at 60mA each, so with 60 LEDs, it could pull 3.6A. In practice, colorful displays use under 50% of this. The regulator is rated for 5A continuous without extra cooling and has a thermal cutoff to shut itself down. I'd still want to do test the whole thing fully assembled and see how hot it gets, especially if it's attached to a plastic case that'll start to deform around 150C.
  • Battery Life: will definitely take a big hit, but I think I read the Teal Sport has a 70C battery that should be able to handle the extra current demand.
  • Minor TODO: Investigate whether and where we should add some power filter caps.
  • MAJOR TODO: We need to add either a battery fuel gauge or a voltage divider so the we can be sure to shut down the LEDs before they add to the risk of over-discharge. That's pretty easy to do, but not shown here because I don't know the details of the Teal drone.
Bill of Materials

There are lots of equivalent parts that would work just as well. This list is heavily weighted to be things I already have on hand. I considered using an M0 Adalogger instead, because it already has the uSD card onboard, but I stuck with the Teensy 3.2 in this diagram so you can use the code from the Supernova Poi project without any modifications.

  • Adafruit DotStar Digital LED Strip - Black 144 LED/m - 0.5 Meter - BLACK: $24.95
  • 2x4-pin JST SM Plug + Receptacle Cable Set: 2x $1.50
  • Teensy 3.2: $19.95
  • TXB0104 Bi-Directional Level Shifter - TXB0104: $3.50
  • Pololu 5V, 5A Step-Down Voltage Regulator D24V50F5: $14.95
  • SparkFun microSD Transflash Breakout $3.95 (OPTIONAL)
  • A toggle switch
  • Wires and connectors.
Circuit Diagram

The circuit is pretty straightforward. Use the 5V regulator to power the Teensy and the DotStar strips. The Teensy I/O are 3.3V, so a level shifter will bring those signals up to the 5V that the DotStar specs require.

A major difference between this and the sample project is using the drone battery instead of strapping another battery on top. The Teal Sport is a pretty small drone and while the extra circuit boards and LED strip holders are very light, adding another battery to the top of the case is not. I think most pilots can live with a shorter flight time for their flashy light show run, but adding an extra battery's worth of weight would mean drastic changes to flight characteristics.

The microSD card is totally optional, and does consume a disproportionate number of wires, so that might be good to skip on the first build. A microSD card is a 3.3V device and can consume up to 150mA, but the 3.3V regulator onboard the Teensy is rated for 250mA.

The barrel jack image for battery power isn't meant to be taken literally. I don't know how hard it'd be to get to battery power on a Teal Sport, especially since you want to make sure that however you connect doesn't damage it.


Code!

Here's where you could go crazy spending time making things fancy. For starters, skip the optional microSD card and follow the wonderful writeup for the Supernova Poi, which includes step-by-step instructions. (It also includes an IR remote control that we'll leave out for this project.)

For my prototype, I'm using the SD card to load images, which I think is a little easier way to work with it. Since the physical parts of this project are speculative (for a Thingiverse contest), then if this project gets some interest or someone wants to mount it on an actual drone, then I'll work on publishing that sample code. (It's pretty simple, but if I can point someone to a tutorial with real tech support first. like Adafruit, that's the place for people to start.)

A fun question for this project is how easy it is to determine the rate of speed of the drone. If it is, then it'd be easy to use that to control the image update speed so images maintain their dimensions in flight and don't get stretched or compressed depending on how fast you're going. A GPS with a fast update rate might do it, but it seems kinda silly to put a GPS on a drone and not have it feeding positions to the flight control board.

There's also commercial pitot tube-based speed sensorts like this one, but I'm not sure how hacker-friendly they are.

• Looking at the LED strip holder attachment bracket and holding a printed strip holder in hand, I think it looks a bit chunkier and beefy than it probably needs to be, especially on such a small drone. If this gets to the "multiple printed revisions test" phase, I'd consider shrinking all those measurements down. (This is where putting in the effort up front to parameterize everything has a big payoff.)

  • Version 1 assumes keeping the weather stripping on the LEDs to protect them from (fabulously brightly colored) crashes, but the strip is a lot more compact without it. You could remove the front cutout and resize the strip holder and print it in transparent filament to create a diffuser and have it be a lot slimmer. It'd also look cool and translucent.

  • It'd be nice to add a wire channel or clips to the back of the LED strips, once the wire routing is finalized. For a first version, I was planning to glue the wires in place with silicone sealant. Either way, you definitely don't want loose wires outside the drone body with spinning rotors!

  • The drone doesn't sit flat anymore. Consider ways to address that. Probably adding anything with mass to the drone is bad, but we could make a little launch platform. (OTOH, a soda can would probably be a perfectly good launch platform, too.)

comments.text: I thought about mounting a powered rotor on top the the drone, with a slip ring to get the wires to the LEDs, so you could spin the POV display around the drone, but the smallest easily available parts looked to me like that idea was even less doable than the obvious problems suggest. (i.e. adding a rotating body that's not part of the intended flight characteristics to a drone was a pretty crazy plan to begin with.)

description.text:
This is a friction fit case for the Pro Micro. It also has a screw on top and back piece to provide further stability.

This is part of a project to create modular components for a portable handheld gaming system. This way novices can assemble any models they want to use and essentially "snap" them together to quickly prototype. The Fusion 360 project file with all the sketches step by step instructions for creating the model (so that you can easily modify it). This is released under the public domain license so you can use it for reference, modify, or incorporate it into your project and sell it.

The top pieces use m2 6mm screws.

Here is a link to the Fusion 360 project that also includes two other Teensy clone cases.
http://a360.co/2iOVCDk

The ornament weighs 15 grams. OpenSCAD code is included.

title: Notebook Mount Phone Display TO SCALE*

description.text:
This is a smartphone mount for your notebook to use while studying or doing homework that will let you display video or online notes, power points, spreadsheets, etc. It's a great idea for those that can work from their phones who like to be lazy and lay in bed while doing homework. The large bookmark style clip is meant to clamp on to the cover and back of the notebook. There are three main parts...

-Phone Clamp (to-scale) with a predetermined gap of Ho=74mm

-Dovetail Mount (to-scale) with mounting holes of do=3mm and depth Do=10mm

-Bookmark Style Clip (to-scale) with a length of Lo=120mm
&
-Bookmark Style Clip (not-to-scale) Lo=120mm

The intent, to fix the difference in tolerance of the mounting holes after re-scaling, was to heat up a bolt (the next size up in diameter) and to try avoid using the slotted mount as a sliding device.

The hardware needed:
-x2 screws/bolts (greater than or equal to) [3mm x10mm] or [1/8" x3/8"]
-x2 washers
-Bic Lighter
-Pliers
-Screwdriver or Allen wrench

HOPE YOU LIKE IT

title: Patrol Lost Board Game
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Designed by Felbrigg Herriot. The game builds the board as it progresses by placing and removing hexagon tiles. It's for two players, one takes control of the "Good Guys" and the other player controls the "Bad Guys". Players move their pieces around the board, one player trying to reach the End tile and the other trying to eliminate the opponents pieces before they reach the End tile.
Combat is resolved by rolling D6's with modifiers being applied.
It can be played solo if the player wishes.
On the hazard tiles I used a Ork style character with a crossbow.
Warhammer style Pieces add character to this game like Space Marines vs Orks.

title: Reach3D BLTouch + Part Cooling Fan Mount

description.text:
This is the mount I designed to mount a BLTouch Smart sensor to the Reach3D printer (http://reach3dprinters.com/). You can also mount a radial fan for part cooling. The fan mounting parts were designed with this particular fan in mind (https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B01K49K358) but should work with any fan with similar dimensions.

You do need to superglue the nozzel to the air funnel. (Align the nozzle carefully!)

The tip of the radial fan will seat firmly down into the top of the air funnel.

Depending on your current setup, you may be able to simply re-use your existing hot end clamps. I've included a set of clamps here, just in case.

Also, this mount was designed around the E3Dv6 hotend. It may not work with clones, as some are longer than the actual E3Dv6 and may throw off the Z offset by too large of a margin.

The BLTouch will mount with it's included screws and nuts. To mount the fan, you will a M3-20mm bolt and nut and 2 x M3-12mm bolts and nuts.

You may also need an extra set of M5 nuts to mount the accessory mount to the hotend carriage. Using the included clamps, you can resess the original nuts into the clamp. Then attach this accessory mount with a second set of nuts. This allows removal of this accessory mount without loosing the clamps holding the hot end.

Once mounted, you will want to do a z-probe and get a good measurement of the z-offset and modify your firmware accordingly.

My offsets are currently set at X: 16, Y: -29, and Z: -0.95.

comments.text: What probe offsets are you using for this in Marlin?
comments.author: sdempsay

author: aaronroma

description.text:
This mount allows you to use the Flexion Extruder with your Hypercube Evolution. It includes a Bltouch sensor mount as well.

The extruder mounts through the stepper motor. To do this remove the top two screws on the stepper motor and replace with 45mm M3 screw going through the top two holes.
The 40mm fan mounts on the front. You will need two spacers. I had two spare from my old duplicator but you could print some from (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1656609). Between the 40mm fan and the spacer is the radial fan mount. I hot glued the radial fan in just to be safe but it really did not need it.

I printed the fan mount with supports and both with 50% infill.

title: Filament runout sensor for Tevo Tarantula (and others)

description.text:
Quick and dirty filament runout sensor. I will be leveraging a RPi3 for this, but there are tutorials on how to wire a runout sensor to the MKS board. This is for 1.75mm filaments only.

For this, you will need:

  • Raspberry Pi running Octoprint
  • I am running Marlin 1.1.5. YMMV if you are running something else...
  • 2x M4x10 socket head cap screws
  • 2 M4 T-nuts (like the ones the printer came with) -OR-
  • 2 M4 threaded inserts (I used McMaster-Carr P/N 94510A040
  • A microswitch. I used an OMRON SS-5GL2T (https://www.amazon.com/ELECTRONIC-COMPONENTS-SS-5GL2T-MICROSWITCH-ROLLER/dp/B011N9VGV8)
  • 2 pieces of 1.75mm filament cut to ~20mm
  • 2 conductor cable
  • Heatshrink
  • Female jumper or some other connector to hook up to the GPIO pins
  • (optional) 2 t-nuts to direct mount this to the frame if desired.
  • (optional) some sort of connectors for quick disconnection of the cable.

The physical assembly should be straight forward for the assembly. If you are not using the press inserts, you just drop the tnuts in the back of the rear clamshell and tighten up. Might be a good idea to do this before mounting to the printer to allow you to tighten the nut in and have it swage into the plastic. I never used that method so I'm not sure!

Solder one conductor of your cable to the relay COM/GND. The other should be soldered to the NO terminal (you can use the NC terminal too, and just change it in Octoprint). Use heatshrink to protect your connections and offer some strain relief. Place the switch in the housing and use the 2 pieces of filament to secure the switch. Depending on your printer performance, you may need to drill (use a 5/64" bit) it out a tad.

After the assembly is done, you will need to wire it to your RPi. I am using the RPi for remote on/off as well, so I opted to build an enclosure for the relay to live. Also, I used a breadboard with a GPIO extension board for ease of wiring. This is totally optional and you can get away with wiring directly to the GPIO header on the RPi. Connect one conductor (doesn't matter which) to your switching pin (I used Pin 24 (BCM8/CE0) for signal) and the other to a ground pin (pin 20 or 25, for example). Congrats, now you are wired.

In Octoprint, download and install the "Filament Sensor Reloaded" plugin. After it is installed, change the pin to 24 (or whatever one you used), leave debounce at 250ms, leave switch type to Normally Open (unless you wired your switch NC!), select board mode, and deselect "Pause print when out of filament". In custom g-code, add the following:
M600 X0 Y0 Z5
This will start the filament change process (M600) and send the print head to home. Follow the prompts on your LCD to complete the filament change.

No more partial rolls!

title: lasermount for Wanhao Duplicator i3 and similar
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
The THING
This is a lasermount for Wanhao Duplicator i3.
The hole distance is 40mm.
This thing may be applicable for similar printers as well.
This mount gets seat where the stock fan was attached earlier.

-
WARNING:
Safety first. Protect your eyes.
Please monitor the laser, don't burn the house.

Lasers are dangerous. Seriously.
Don't play with guns and lasers.
No distraction, please.
Have an eye.
Be prepared for the not foreseeable.

  • Please carry protectiv glasses ALL the time you have the lasermodule physicaly connected to the printers board.
  • DO NOT stare into the laser beam or watch the laser beam burning the work surface.
  • Limit the time watching the laser beam even at low power when you adjust the focus.
    Cheap goggles can not withstand radiation stronger than a few mW.
    It may happen the laser powers up even you if you are not prepared for this event.

  • Do not cross the laser beam with your hand, never.

  • Add a breaker switch, strongly recommended.

  • Monitor the laser safely:

    • The cheap version: put the printer behind the next wall, hook up a USB-webcam with long cable (ususally no longer than 3m) and you are done

    • The comfortable solution (stream a video):
      I'm using iChat/Contacts streaming the video from a webcam I have mounted next to the printer. Than I watch the guy working from another Mac trough the video streamed to this machine even if it were in another room, town, country, hey.

You do not operate a bunch of (almost deadsilent) Mac Mini?
Sorry guys, gals - THIS is not my fault.
They can be had 2nd hand as of made from 2009 up to 2012 ( no younger please, sorry for that Apple made crap with soldered on RAM and CPU) for a few bucks and they run older OS (OSX 10.8.5 ,Linux, Windoze7,8 ) with almsost no crappy flat, material design, i.e. grey on black. Take some precautions, they will run safer than the phone or computer you are exposing with threats from the internet day by day.

Operating a computer OS with a decent manually reduced configured user interface IS sort of protecting my eyes as well.
Please, no gimmicks, no animations, no transparency, no glass, no notification center, no bubbles, no swipe....
Heck, there is a lot of shit that hurt my eyes. Please stay away from that.

It's up to you NOT to follow the fresh crappy unergonomical shit the computer industry serves you every year with. RANT /Off
.............................................................

The lasermount:
The picture shows the development version. It has been screwed and glued together from two pieces.

The laser module 2.5Watts (33,5x33,5mm) has to be secured safely.
(There are lower powered laser moduls that share the same mechanical design.)
Feed 4 screws (3mmx16mm) from the bottom of the mount into the 4 holes (next to the laser optics) at the face of the module.
If you have trouble screwing them in easily, cut 3mm threads there first.

I had used screws for plastic first but have cut 3mm threads later.
This (using metric screws 3mm) is the better way to mount (and release) the module I guess.
For videos on making similar mounts see the links collection below
.............................................................

The files:

  • the mount .stl
  • GCODE papercut house2 (can be made in a few minutes)
  • GCODE of a little Witch riding a broom (can be made in a few minutes)
  • GCODE of Bughati P100 (very slow)
  • GCODE of S-3 plane (very slow)
  • wich files
    The GCODE is ready for engraving wood (laser power settings for the 2.5Watt module).
    The settings I have used are included at the begin of the code(textfile).
    Adjust the z-hight, the laser strength as needed according to the material and your lasermodule.
  • lensadadjuster knob
    https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2655664
    .............................................................

Usage:
The first application I have used for testing is available at the website of the makers of the Inkscape-Laser-addon. This particular programm is intended for making pcb.
It is much easier to use than the Inkscape stuff. If you are just beginning the laser stuff try this first.

-Put in a BMP-graphic.
Have it prepared by making it high contrast BW.
No colour, no greytone please. This way you have more control about the result.
This is true for every programm you are using for making gcode from a pictures outline.
This program will transform every picture internally to BW tough and cut the lower half off.

-Please have in mind there is an offset X:+15mm Y:-75mm.
(This roughly equals the distance the laserbeam is away from the nozzle tip.)
With no offset compensation the position of the first dot the laser burns will be BEFORE the printbed and shifted to the right side.
If your stock material starts at the printbed frontedge you have to put in an y-offset of 75mm or more. Or you may move the stock board physicaly toward you, let it hang over the bed. Otherwise the laser hits the surface on your desk.
Anyway,

-Let it calculate the gcode now.
This program generates code for burning the wood like an old dot lineprinter / a raster scanner, very slow. It's ok to get the idea.
DL at the end

-Put the generated gcode into Pronterface/Repetier-Host.
...........................................

Make some paper(art)work
the goal drawing, punching, cutting fine lines on regular paper

have set the z-hight to 20mm now, refocussed the laserbeam again
have my ( 2.5Watt) laser power set to app. 45%
take just the amount where your laser starts burning the paper
speed at F=200 punches / cuts paper (80g/m2) , very slow indeed
That gives me almost a continuous line.
This is usefull for making paper models, making plans for planes, Origami or similar artwork

You can increase power and speed the same time, do some experiments.
Check if the edges, (areas along the line) are not scorched to much as well.
Perfect result, cut the line only, have no visible burn marks. ok dream on.

If your laser needs higher duty cycle you can increase the moving speed as well.
This time it would be better using a LOW power lasermodule.
For the reason why read on below.

...........................................

Problem:
dottet lines where continuous lines should be, caused by low PWM frequency moving the laser along the axis at regular speed

Probably a solution if your board runs a more laser specific FW like some grbl / lasersaur.
Set a higher PWM frequency; FW recompilation requiered.
http://github.com/gnae/grbl/issues/55
https://groups.google.com/forum/#!msg/lasersaur/bJ2l5-dlsJo/27is2g43dtEJ

I want ENGRAVING , not cutting trough, baby!
The board (FW) does not do a good job engraving sensitive surfaces like wood (sort of, made from compressed fibers) with powerfull lasermoduls with INTEGRATED electronics that need to be regulated down externaly by pulsing the supplied power(12Volt) provided by the fan output.
I have encountered problems running a lasermodule (2.5Watts , 455nm wavelength) at low power (low PWM frequency, low PWM duty cycle).
The module runs roughly only half the time or less (M106 S100) on the pulsing power provided by the fan port.
This results in dottet lines where continuous lines should be.
Have to seek for a weak module (25mW) or one with with external board that has the electronics connected to the power permanently and regulates the current going through the LED by it self.
Then the input can be fed into the TTL-input switching the laser radiaton on or off only.
Tradeoff: no true (adaptive power) regulation from the software

description.text:
Make my headphones stupid again!
I've got the plantronics backbeat pro 2 and everything would be fantastic, except I am using them in a bed and that wasn't what good people of plantronics had in mind.
As you may know or not (as apparently I didn't) the "smart" function buttons are on the flat sides of the cups so as you lean on a pillow you will simply press them and beep the next video plays, beep the thing is making a call, beep, beep, beep......in my bed I want stupid BT headphones, not ones that will call police or quick-order pizza when I fall asleep watching the new star trek tv series. (and that is going to happen with the way things are shaping up. Space whales! In a space! Mushroom spores to teleport across a galaxy when you hook them up to a dude!. .whatever the script writers are smoking these days must be potent)
But fear not I have a 3d printer and a caliper and 20 minutes to spare and I am not afraid to use any of those things. And no need for mushroom spores this time.

Now, I didn't want to make permanent changes in case I will change my mind and use them outside where I would badly want to make calls, use them as headset and talk very loudly so everyone on the street could hear my conversation with my cleaner and do all that while having my phone in my trousers. (fat chance, I look like an idiot even without doing all that)
So I am not going to destroy anything, just replace the button faceplates with dumb faceplates. And if the headphones break and need warranty repair, I can swap things back and nobody would be wiser.

Now first how to remove the original faceplates - they are just snapped in with few tabs, but look on my pics where are the tabs. (left and rigth side are different)
Use thin plastic tool or something thin like a flexible palette knife, or just first try to pry it with your fingernail, then stick the palette knife to pop them off. The tabs will not get broken if you are careful. The side with play button has only 2 tabs up and down, the other side with the call button has 4 tabs.

You want to print the two L and R inserts - they are perfect fit. I made them customizable. In my case I wanted to glue a leather on top of my new insert because I am was born with a leather silver spoon in my mouth and I am very fancy. Very fancy!
But you can print other tops - I gave you two - a simple grid and a Daenerys Targaryen Dragon crest (she doesn't know). Those should be glued on top of the printed inserts.
But you can be creative - you can print the insert in one color then print the top part in another color and glue them. Or you may sandwitch some film between those things - it is up to you.
I went with just a classy look for the above mentioned posh reasons and I had the same leather that the headband is made of from some old sofa. (or close to it) You can also glue some exotic wood veneer (about 1-1.5mm) that would look very posh too.
You may use some small sticky tape to hold the inserts in. I wanted to make them removable eventually so the tabs are just push in, not hook tabs as on original.
The volume rotary is not affected by this mod.

title: ID Badge, RSA Key and 2nd card holder

description.text:
This is a remix of devivero0186 original RSA key badge holder.
Suggested settings:

  • Scale up by 2-3%
  • Less than 1.4mm first layer. It has a relatively small footprint for its height.
  • 1.5mm or less layer height.
  • Use a lighter or heat gun to loosen or tighten the RSA key slot. With 2% up-scaling it is a very tight fit.

I needed a badge holder that has a RSA key slot and could hold a 2nd card.

A slot was added in the middle to slide in a second card with two offset bars to provide tension so it doesn't fall out. A window was added to the back so you can use a finger to slide the card out. I ran into a small issue of the card getting locked in place but a quick run through the slot with a nail file loosened it just enough to make the inner card slide out easily but not fall out. I dont want to alter the source file because printer tolerances, filament shrinkage, or evil spirits could make it not work, and 2 seconds with a nail file (if needed) is fine for me.
The lanyard attachment point was moved to a top mounted tab and holes made for a beaded chain.

Always wear proper safety gear when working with fast rotating parts!

BTW my output file does not contain facets, I am not sure why the preview is showing a faceted object. It should be perfectly round.

title: Gcode Power steering / Pilotage alim par Gcode sur Hictop 3DP17

description.text:
In French at the end - en francais à la fin

On my Hictop 3DP17 printer, I used Pin 11 to control the power on or off.

WIRING
Pin 11 is usually used to detect the end of the wire when printing.
I connected the pin 11 to a Solid State Relay SSR that you can find here: https://www.amazon.fr/gp/product/B0185PVVG8/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o06_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1
This SSR relay contains an optocoupler that protects the motherboard.
It is connected to 0v, 5v and Pin11 output on one side
It is connected to the 220v as a switch: in series

REPROGRAMMING
I reprogrammed the Marlin Firmware:
PINS.H file: added #define PS_ON_PIN 11 at the end of PINS.H file
Configuration.H file: #define POWER_SUPPLY 2
This makes it possible to control the power supply by means of the commands M80 (ignition) and M81 (stop)

USE
You need to power the motherboard through the USB socket to boot.
at the beginning of the code (start.gcode in Cura) we must add "M80".
at the end of the code (end.gcode in Cura) we must add "M81".
You can also control the power supply in the Marlin Firmware menu.

This publication follows: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2448359

EN FRANCAIS

Sur mon imprimante Hictop 3DP17, j'ai utilisé la Pin 11 pour commander l'allumage ou l'arret de l'alimentation.

CABLAGE
La pin 11 est habituellement utilisé pour détecter la fin du fil lors d'une impression.
J'ai relié la pin 11 à un relais statique SSR (solid state relay) que vous trouverez ici : https://www.amazon.fr/gp/product/B0185PVVG8/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o06_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1
Ce relais SSR contient un opto-coupleur qui protège la carte mère.
Il est relié aux 0v, 5v et sortie Pin11 d'un coté
Il est relié au 220v comme un interrupteur : en serie

REPROGRAMMATION
J'ai reprogrammé le Firmware Marlin :
Fichier PINS.H : ajout #define PS_ON_PIN 11 en fin de fichier PINS.H
Fichier configuration.H : #define POWER_SUPPLY 2
Cela permet de piloter l'alimentation à l'aide des commandes M80 (allumage) et M81 (arret)

UTILISATION
Il faut alimenter la carte mère par la prise USB pour démarrer .
en début de code (start.gcode dans Cura) il faut ajouter "M80".
en fin de code (end.gcode dans Cura) il faut ajouter "M81".
Vous pouvez aussi piloter l'alimentation dans le menu du Firmware Marlin.

Cette publication fait suite à : https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2448359

This is a cable router designed for 8" Celestron telescopes equipped with the Starizona, Hyperstar focal reducer. The traditional method of routing cables is to run them straight over the corrector plate. But this results in diffraction spikes. If instead you run the cables over the corrector plate in a nice circular arc, the diffraction spikes are minimized.

To use, tape your cables to this form with electrical tape and mount the form to the front edge of your telescope.

I designed this thing using Alibre design. I have included the source file for those with this program. I printed it in PLA, but I imagine just about any material would do.

11/13/17 - I added a version for the 11" Celestron Hyperstar system. Note: I have not test fitted the 11" version yet, so it is a work in progress.

11/15/17 - I tested the part on an 11" Celestron at Starizona and it seems to fit. I have removed the "Work-In-Progress" flag for now.

12/3/17 - I added a version for the 9.25" Celestron Hyperstar system.

A block to mount your linear bearings to with one 5mm ziptie. Designed to fit IGUS LMU8 bearings. Fits 15mm outer diameter x 25mm or shorter.
The purpose is to provide a light, minimally constraining and easy to use mount.
Bearings are attached with a single ziptie to allow for the bearing to pivot around its center point and not bind on the linear rod. Applying torque and pressure in various directions after installing will cause the bearings to settle in and slide freely over the linear rod.

As pictured, the purpose for this item was to create a LEGO-based Pi Camera mount that could be attached to a MakerBeam rail.

Adaptor for LEGO brick attaches to small MakerBeam rail (https://www.makerbeam.com/makerbeam/beams/). The Pi Camera mount will accept a 1x2 "gimbal" LEGO piece (I think I got some from a LEGO store, but also found here - https://www.ebay.com/itm/LEGO-Plate-1-x-2-with-Small-Towball-Socket-on-Side-Towball-on-Side-4-sets or https://www.ebay.com/itm/NEW-10-PAIRS-Lego-DARK-Gray-Plate-1x2-TOWBALL-Side-1x2-Gray-Plate-BALL-SOCKET-/ - web search = 'small towball and socket lego')

Printed parts on a Printrbot Simple Maker 1405, "standard" settings. I had to trim a bit and press firmly to get the real Lego brick to attach, but once pressed into place, sit firmly, which is all I need. I'm sure if I used my Prusa i3MK2, would have been a better fit and easier to remove/replace bricks. Similar for the camera mount - a bit tight, but just used x-acto and a little heat to help the fit the 1x2 LEGO - glue/epoxy would also work fine. I will update the model when I have time.

To attach the Pi Camera (designed for v2, but should hold v1, too), >=5mm M2 screws can be used.

description.text:
This is a spool holder that will print fairly quickly. It mounts to either the left or right side of your AM8 3D printer (or similar). The benefit to this is it essentially adds a spool holder to your printer that doesn't take any more space.

You need to one M8 threaded rod and 3 M8 nuts and some washers wouldn't hurt. I need to add a filament guide to prevent the filament unwinding from the spool. The files "V2" and "V2 Alternate" are different. The alternative is similar to V1 with changes to the inner diameter. The V2 is cone-shaped, hopefully adding compatibility for other spools.

EDIT: the versions called "Universal Spool Holder 24-56mm Remix" and "Universal Spool Holder Remix - no supports or bearings needed" are the best ones. Just print one of those, and "Spool_holder_V2_Alternate.stl" plus "2040_endcap_with_8mmhole.STL" and you will be good to go.

title: Evolve skateboard belt cover stand GTX 107mm

description.text:
This is a replacement belt cover for the Evolve GTX skateboards which also provides a flat surface so you can stand the skateboard on it's end.

This has only been tested with my Bamboo GTX with Evolve's 107mmwheels. Which means if you have different wheels or different weight distribution it will not be balanced.
There are other versions on thingiverse for different wheel sizes.

You will also need some new screws (M4 x 10 screws work well)

USE AT YOUR OWN RISK!

You can see some obvious flaws in it. This is not meant to be a perfectly stable storage solution. It will however allow you to put the board on the ground quickly when at the store or for moments you're carrying your board and need two hands.

It has only been tested on my own skateboard so it may need some tweaking for other setups where the weight isn't distributed as evenly. I'll probably update this as I tweak the appearance of it.

title: Dry Box Filament Passage with Filter

description.text:
I was looking for a filament passage that prevents the filament from falling into the box and keep the filament in the inside dry and clean.

After printing the passage I cut an ordinary sponge into little pieces. Next I screwed the passage from the inside to the box, took 3 pieces of the sponge and stuffed them into that passage right around the threaded filament. Finally i screwed the cap on it.
The more sponge you add, the more power the extruder needs to pull it out of the box.
You may have to adjust the holes for the filament by using an screwdriver or an driller.

With this passage your filament will stay dry and clean.

No support needed.

print_settings.Notes:: Increase extrusion if it leaks.

description.text:
Slightly improved Ice-based timed lock. Compared to the original this one has:

  • internal expansion ribs to reduce strain as the water freezes
  • A thicker key with external ribs to hold the ice better
  • Reduced overhangs and no bridges for easier printing
  • A flat-bottomed internal cavity to reduce leaks from slicer-created geometry

Freeze the pin in the body, and at room temperature, it will take 2-3 hours for the ice to melt enough to release the pin. It's a nice alternative to cobbling together an electromechanical timed lock, and more reliable as you're not in a freezer :P

Printer:

Monoprice Select Mini v2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.175

Infill:

25% body, 50-100% key

Notes:

Stand the body on end. Lay the key flat. Designed for 0.5mm extrusion width, 3 perimeters. 0.15-0.30 layers should work.

Use 20-25% infill on the body to allow the ice to expand. Infill the key 50-100% for strength.

Works great with PETG. My PLA print of the original version works too, so I expect PLA to be fine here. Untested if the ribs actually fix the exploding body problem with ABS.

Increase extrusion if it leaks.

title: Minetest Pipeworks models
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
If you've played Minetest (the open source alternative to Minecraft), you've probably seen my Pipeworks mod in use on some servers. If not, you've probably at least seen someone mention it in a chat somewhere. What, you never heard of it? Oh...well here it is anyway, after a fashion. :-)

A while back I had got the idea in my head that I should be able to 3d-print some of the models I've been making for the game, and Pipeworks has always seemed like a good candidate for it.

Here then are all of the pipe-related models from the mod, altered to be more friendly to 3d printing. I've kept the outward appearance of the printable models at close as possible to the originals (in most cases, they're identical). In the case of the pump and grating, the metallic mesh look is normally provided by the in-game textures, so I've modified the printable models to create a similar effect using actual model geometry instead. This repository does not include the "tube" items from the Pipeworks project, at least not yet.

All of these models are designed to be printed without rafts or supports. I've tried to minimize the amount of curvy top-side surfaces as I was rotating and cutting the pipe models, but there's only just so much one can do when you're dealing with something like a 5-way junction. :-P

These models are scaled up to 50 times the size of the original models, but even so, they're still at 1/20 scale (that is, a printed pipe is about 5cm long, versus in-game where it's one node length, or one meter).

I've cut the models apart for easy printing and assembly, but this is not a snap-together kit (maybe I'll implement that some time later). For now, I figured you'd just glue everything together the way you want it. These models are solid all the way through, so don't expect to move liquids through them. :-)

The pump, valve, and a few others are cut in such a way that, if you tell your slicer to separate them into their respective individual parts (e.g. the "Split" function in Slic3r), you can print the different pieces in different colors (for example, pump body in black or dark grey, its metallic parts in silver, and the light dome in red or green), to try to mimic the in-game appearance of the models.

To join the assembled models together, you'll need one or more of the "peg.stl" model. If you need an extra flange or two, I've included .stl's for them, also (there are two types; in the majority of cases, the "hollow" one is what you want).

I've also uploaded each of the models' Blender work files, in addition a .blend of the various kibble that went into transforming the original model files into 3d-printable form, though in some cases the models' cutouts do not match what's in that file (deepened holes to account for bridging of their top-inside faces, mostly).

If you want the original models from the Pipeworks mod, get them from the Pipeworks repository on Github.

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Clone

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.1 mm

Infill:

10-20%

Notes:

Important: Make sure your printer is well-calibrated -- accurate part dimensions are important, especially in the peg-and-hole connections throughout these models. That said, I've given all dimension-sensitive holes and pegs a 0.2 mm to 0.3 mm deep 45° bevel on their on-build-plate edges, to help counteract flaring on the first few layers. In any case, pegs fit into their respective holes, and flanges onto their respective pegs, with only moderate force. Expect some pounding and twisting to get parts to settle together right, depending on the printed quality.

I recommend printing this slow, at a high-quality setting, as there is a fair bit of fine detail (especially the pipes' flanges). For a ballpark figure, the "6-way" model should take around two hours when printed at 30 mm/sec with 0.1 mm layers and 15% infill.

If you're using a metallic filament, please note that the sheen of such plastic will not be consistent from one pipe shape to another, or between an upright-printed pipe and a pipe that had to be laid down for printing (or within a model that has both orientations, such as the 6-way junction). Vapor smoothing may help this.

I tried to make sure that everything fits together without any trimming, but do have your hobby knife handy.

When you're gluing things together, of course you want to take care to make sure everything is right, but pay particular attention when gluing flanges. You'll want to make sure the flanges are rotated so that the little bolts on one side will align properly with the bolts on the other side of the joint when you put two pipes together. The bolt pattern is symmetrical, so simply aligning any bolt with the split where a pipe was cut in half, or toward the "top" or one "side" of the model is sufficient.

Maybe at some point, I'll key the models' pieces to deal with that.

description.text: Empty spools laying around were getting on my nerves but I could not get myself to throw it away. Then I saw on ALL3D about the storage solution using empty spools. Unfortunately it was very difficult to get to the free files so I designed my own.

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Clone

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

10%

Notes:

No pro-printing needed.

Some design details

All thingies were designed from scratch.

I have got 3 types of spools, being, eSUN "narrow" (shallow), eSUN "wider" (deeper) and CCTREE.

The eSUN "Narrow" accommodates "drawers" of up to 27mm height including 2mm bottom thickness of drawer.
The eSUN "wider" accommodates "drawers of up to 54mm height including 2mm bottom thickness. The eSUN "wider" can actually take or be redesigned to take two layers of trays.
The CCTREE accommodates drawers of 55mm height including 2mm bottom thickness.

The "height" or depth (as might want to call it) makes it possible to have "shallow" or "deep" trays. according to need.

To top it all off and thus going a step further than the original idea I also made a "stand" to keep the spools nice in one stack thus using less space. You may add a "right-thru" bolt or threaded rod for the drawers to swing in and out or just make each storage spool with 2 swing-in swing-out drawers.

I have included some SketchUP files as well. However be warned that changing some of these may have unwanted results

ENJOY

In the objective to shave some mass on the ANET's Y and X carriages, here is a standard sized LM8UU holder or housing.

It is designed to exactly fit the LM8UU linear bearing or any plastic one.
As it is parametric, you can customize it (open in customizer button at the bottom right of the image) in order to adapt it to your bearing and to the quality of your printer ;-)

Everything included, more than 20 grams per housing are won. Which means 84 grams recovered only for the housings of the Y carriage. If you change the LM8UU by those printed ones (highly advised ! see here: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2537701) 50 other grams are shaved ...

==> total gain of 134 grams... not too bad !

You will need small pins in order to lock the bearing in their housing (small holes are printed to insert the pin right in place, see the blue arrows in the picture of the X carriage).

My goal was to make those housing so that in case of wearing of the bushings they could be changed, on the ANET A8, without having to remove the bed and maybe, even without having to level the bed !
Just push the Y rod accross the frame, remove the pin, push the old bushing from behind and pull it ! With the spiral vase bushings, as they are springy, they will quit the housing very easily...

Last word, the original M4 screws are just too short for this housing, you'll have to procure 10 mm long ones.

Printer:

ANET A8

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm with a 0.4 mm noozle

Infill:

20%

Notes:

print them in PLA.

Once finished, just gently sand the back on a flat surface.
If needed, adjust the inside diameter so that a standard LM8UU may slide with friction.

let's customize it ...

Parametrization allows several options :

// play with this value to trim the screw diameter. (If you use threads set it to 4 mm)
screw_diam = 4.1;

// bushing outer diameter
bushing_diam = 15.1; // <====== you can enlarge or reduce a bit the hole for the bushing

// do you want M4 nuts ?
nuts = "yes" ; //["yes","no"] <===== If yes is selected you will get hexagonal slots in which M4 nuts will nicely fit (as on the picture)

// do you want threads ? (if yes set the screw diam to 4mm)
threads = "no" ; //["yes","no"] <===== this is an attempt to print ready tapped screw hole. My feeling is that the thread is not very robust ...

// do you want bottom restriction ?
bottom = "yes" ; //["yes","no"] <===== if yes is selected there will be a flange printed at the bottom of the housing and therefore only one pin axis. If no , two pins holes are printed

my other ANET A8 mods

If you like this mod for the ANET A8, you might be interested in my other ANET's designs all of them are here to improve the ANET A8 printer...

description.text:
Modified the design:

  • added holes ( done in tinkercad.com):
    • cooling on the side
    • SD card for easy swap
    • custom DC connector (goes to bat power)
    • moved WiFi holes down a bit

Case feels pretty cool to the touch. very satisfied.
