title: Cocoon Create Model Maker (Wanhao Duplicator i3 Mini) mount with part-cooling fan

description.text:
The Cocoon Create Model Maker (aka Wanhao i3 Duplicator Mini) was recently distributed in Australia through the retailer: Aldi (sold for $299 AUD).

Prints off the CCMM showed promise but had the usual drooping and stringing due to a lack of a dedicated part-cooling fan.

Intrigued with the design and having a natural tendency to open things and look inside, I opened the CCMM to reveal the board and power supply being used. Upon further inspection of the board, I realised that there was an extra port for a ‘fan’ which was not used. The existing fan (used to cool both the heatsink and act as a psuedo part cooling fan) was connected to a constant 24v port, hence why whenever the printer is turned on, the fan would turn on too. So I took a spare 5015 radial fan and plugged it into the “fan” port. With Octoprint I sent the command M106 S255 and confirmed that the fan responded to my gcode command. Unfortunately I couldn’t seem to modulate the fan speed, regardless the speed that I sent to it. Regardless, it’s much better than having no control at all.

Fan duct used: Spriya for E3D
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2305596

Heatsink fan used: E3D v6 Hotend - 40mm Fan Duct
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:354723

Printer Brand:

Wanhao

Printer:

Wanhao Duplicator i3 Plus

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

50-70%

Notes:

Print with ABS or other heat resistant material.

Tools, Parts and Assembly

Additional Slicer Info:

The hardest part to print is the fan arm. It comes into the slicer software in the wrong orientation. I remedied in Simplify3d by using the "Place Surface on Bed" function. This gave me 29.72, 85.89 and 70.04 for XYZ axises respectively.

The backplate needs to be printed with the back part (surface that meets the bearing holder) down.

The clamp preferably be printed in an upright position so that the grain of the print runs around the clamp rather than vertically which hinder its clamping strength.

Tools Required:

M3 thread tapper.
Vise-grips
Shift spanner

Parts Required:

4x M3x15mm bolts
1x M4x25mm bolt
1x M4 nut
2x No.4 self-tapping screws
5015 Radial Fan
Ceramic tape
Kapton tape

Note: You can forego the Ceramic and Kapton tape if you have an E3D silicone heat-block sock. However some sort of insulation on the heater block is essential as the part-cooling fan will cool the heat-block and may trigger a false thermal runaway alarm.

Once all the parts have been printed, remove all support material. On the backplate thread tap the two holes on the front for the 2 m3x15mm bolt to go through. Then thread tap the two holes on the fan arm which the two bolts will attach to.

Assembly:

  1. Cut all cable-ties holding the wires and bowden tube together.
  2. Remove the wire sheath to expose the wires and set aside.
  3. Remove the bowden tube from the hotend.
  4. Unscrew the existing fan and
  5. Remove your existing metal back plate with the M4 allen key that’s included with the printer.
    Note: be careful when handling the hotend, as you do not want to break the wires on the heater cartridge or thermistor..Also ensure to insulate your hot-end block before installation.
  6. Using a vise grip, grab the top of the heatsink, so that it does not easily rotate. Then with the shift-spanner, unscrew the bowden tube adapter. Then remove your hotend from the old cage and set aside.
  7. Using the screws undone in step 5, affix the newly printed backing plate to the new bearing blocks
  8. Attach the fan arm, screw in the two m3x15mm bolts from the side which faces the bowden attachment.
  9. Place your hot-end into the grooves of the new backplate.
  10. Put two m3x15mm bolts through the clamp and then screw into the backing plate. Ensure that you alternate the tightening of the screws to ensure that there is an equal amount of torque on the clamp.
  11. Attach your Radial fan using the m4 bolt and nut. Adjust the height of your fan so that it’s flow will cool the nozzle but not the heat-block.
  12. Guide the radial fan wire together with the existing wire loom and cover with the sheath.
  13. Remove the back panel on the tower using the m2 allen key included with the printer.
  14. Once the back is exposed, wrap around or affix using cable ties, the radial fan wire with the existing wires.
  15. Push the radial fan wire down the hole into the bottom.
  16. Re-install your backplate.
  17. Open the bottom of the printer and plug in the radial fan plug into the “fan” socket. Ensure that the wires are kept neat and will not foul against the existing cooling fan.
  18. If you’re using the Spriya fan duct, you will need to angle the hotend so that front faces of the block are parallel to the duct outputs.
  19. Finally attach your 40mm heatsink cooler using no.4 self tapping screws.
  20. Once fully assembled process PID autotune through Octopi or Pronterface. I typically try for 8 cycles. More info: http://marlinfw.org/docs/gcode/M303.html
  21. Print!

description.text:
This weekend I bought a game called Mouse Trap (Muizenval in Dutch). For some reason this is a MENSA kids game. It has some mistakes in design, and one big irritating flaw.

description.text:
I seriously hoped that buying the E3D Titan Extruder would help with my skipping issues. Guess what?!

So here is a remix of my original Filter & Oiler For Bowden Extruder, this time mountable on the E3D Titan Extruder.

  • Use one of the longer screws supplied with the Titan to mount it.
  • Add a drop or two of oil weekly, depending on your extruder's performance. I found that sunflower frying oil works best due to the higher smoking point.
  • Doubles as a filter, useful for removing dust from your filament if you are printing in a dusty environment.
  • Hopper-like design on top to minimize spillage when adding oil.
  • Easy access to the oiling sponge from the side using a removable cover.

I have also included the Blender file in case you want to edit it further.

comments.text: Great idea, i will try to integrate this into Kyle's housing. BtW, regarding your skipping issues, you should check out Kyle's Housing / my remix of it. The stability of the printed housing is much better, so when you put some pressure on the spring, it will not bend the housing, but simply put more pressure on the filament as you would expect it. This stopped my titans from skipping, after one of the original cases broke,due to the pressure.  Simply search for "titan extruder housing remix".

author: geo_geox

description.text:
Phone stand will suit a Samsung Galaxy Alpha in s-view case or similar sized phones. Maximum size is width 70mm (2.75") x depth 13mm (0.5"). I've uploaded versions for speaker holes on the LHS or RHS.

The speaker sound is routed through a chamber at the back to reduce the treble and enhance the bass frequencies, resulting in a fuller sound.

Printer Brand:

Duplicator 4

Printer:

Wanhao

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Notes:

There are overhangs and bridges inside the model, but any well set up printer should have no trouble printing this design. Support can not be used due to the closed structure; You'd never be able to remove it.
Print this thick - I used 4 shells and 1mm floors and ceilings. The heavier the better.

My first pass at this design was simply the stand diverting the speaker output to the grille at the front and sounded terrible. The high frequencies were enhanced and it sounded very sibilant and scratchy, but it got me thinking . . .

Pass 2 was to add the chamber at the rear, with the opening directly underneath the speaker hole, effectively 'sitting behind' the grille. This gave an improvement in sound but I thought I could do better.

For the third iteration the speaker output is directed backwards into the chamber with the port to the front grille at the far end, so the sound waves take the long way around. This was a great improvement and resulted in an apparent boosting of the middle and lower frequencies.

The final print was a tidying-up exercise and was printed with thicker walls and roof in a slightly more flexible PLA.

The difference between the stands was clearly audible in speech and music, and even more so when I played white noise or a 100 to 10KHz sweep tone through them. I used Digital Antics Test Tone Generator for this.

Obviously there's scope for a lot more experimentation here (size of chamber, addition of baffle material etc) but I'm satisfied with the sound that comes out so I'm presenting this as a finished item.

description.text:
I have not had the best of luck painting PLA and stickers don't seem to last very long, so I decided to modify Ekobots-Rubik's Cube. I indented each outward facing face slightly then printed up a bunch of tiles to fit into the indents. The core is still the original file (so I didn't upload it).

This is not a "Speed" cube by any means but it is fully functional.I printed it all in PLA and used 6 M3x25 with 6 M3 washers.

UPDATE: I was having trouble with the screws backing out of the core after several twists on my original cube, so I made yet another modification. I modified the core itself with 3mm nut insets. The nuts were very tight already, but, for added assurance, I glued them in place to prevent them from moving. I also use white lithium grease to make it twist even smoother.

Printer:

Anycubic Kossel Delta

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

2

Infill:

20

Notes:

Not the easiest of prints. I orientated each piece with the insets facing up.

On my second print, I used PETG and 80% infill (wanted to make sure it didn't break). Probably an overkill, but for something relatively small, not really an issue for me.
Assembled using the 6 screws and washers I purchased from Ace Hardware. I did trim down the face tiles slightly and then secured them in place with Gorilla Glue.

description.text:
A pinball insert (table roll over switch) Using cheap SS49E hall effect sensors and neodymium magnets.

Video about it here: https://youtu.be/tZuv5gnS2lc

All parts printed in PLA.
The clear lens in PLA transparent.
For testing i printed a large apron around the sensor so i could roll the ball across the sensor.
I the final design i would only print the lens to fit within the sensor case.
The single LED will probably be replaced with 3xAPA102 LED's...more info on the why later :)

It's not the easiest way to make a switch but it won't alter the balls trajectory and it's completely
reliable.

I may or may not include this in the final design.

Parts used...
3x SS49E Hall effect sensor
6x Neodymium magnet N35 5mmx2mm

I connected the 3 hall effect sensors in parallel so that any increase in voltage from either of the 3 sensors would trigger a ball present. In the video i am using a arduino (Wemos D1) but in the final design it will be a simple resistor and transistor pair that will provide a signal much like any switch would.

There are over 5,000 Spool Holders on Thingiverse. Its impossible to choose a suitable one because the descriptions are very scant. Files need to be downloaded to get the essential dimensions.

A 16mm ID x65 lg Pvc pipe is used to support the spool. It is held in place with the 2 end caps and an M6 bolt and nut .

description.text:
Just a set of motherboard fan holders to suit the Wanhao Duplicator 6 and Monoprice Ultimate and any other compatible clones.

These will replace the standard fan holder that blocks some of the airflow and causes excessive noise.

There are 4 types of holder:

  • Single 40mm fan
  • Dual 40mm fans
  • Single 50mm fan
  • Dual 50mm fans

The 40mm fan uses M3 screws and nuts to affix the fan(s) to the mounts, and the 50mm mount uses standard fan screws as used in computer cases and the like (or M4 screws or whatever you have that fits)

You'll also have to replace the standard fan mount screws with longer M3 ones with nuts and washers etc.

I've supplied STEP and Rhino 3D (.3dm) files so you can remix and stuff if needed. Just be cool and credit me somehow. :)
